intro: Acroglyphe hispidula, commonly known as the hairy acroglyphe, is a small, herbaceous plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic compounds and often divided, compound leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and thrives in full sun, exhibiting a low, spreading growth habit. Its small, white or greenish flowers appear in umbels, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Acroglyphe hispidula is adapted to withstand drought and heat, making it a resilient species in harsh environments.
